sn35.120:0.2.eng: 12. The World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation

sn35.120:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā sāriputto sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn35.120:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn35.120:1.1.comm: This discourse situates the six senses within the path of practice known as the “Gradual Training”, set out in full at DN 2.

sn35.120:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn35.120:1.2.eng: Then a certain mendicant went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn35.120:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.120:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side, and said to him,

sn35.120:1.4.pli: “saddhivihāriko, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvatto”ti.
sn35.120:1.4.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, a mendicant protégé of mine has resigned the training and returned to a lesser life.”
sn35.120:1.4.comm: The saddhivihārika (“protégé”) was a resident student ordained under the protection and guidance of a mentor (upajjhāya).

sn35.120:2.1.pli: “Evametaṃ, āvuso, hoti indriyesu aguttadvārassa, bhojane amattaññuno, jāgariyaṃ ananuyuttassa.
sn35.120:2.1.eng: “That’s how it is, reverend, when someone doesn’t guard the sense doors, eats too much, and is not committed to wakefulness.

sn35.120:2.2.pli: ‘So vatāvuso, bhikkhu indriyesu aguttadvāro bhojane amattaññū jāgariyaṃ ananuyutto yāvajīvaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ santānessatī’ti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
sn35.120:2.2.eng: It is quite impossible for such a mendicant to maintain the full and pure spiritual life for the rest of their life.

sn35.120:2.3.pli: ‘So vatāvuso, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro, bhojane mattaññū, jāgariyaṃ anuyutto yāvajīvaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ santānessatī’ti ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
sn35.120:2.3.eng: But it is quite possible for a mendicant to maintain the full and pure spiritual life for the rest of their life if they guard the sense doors, eat in moderation, and are committed to wakefulness.

sn35.120:3.1.eng: And how does someone guard the sense doors?

sn35.120:3.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
sn35.120:3.2.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

sn35.120:3.3.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ, cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
sn35.120:3.3.eng: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.

sn35.120:3.4.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

sn35.120:3.5.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

sn35.120:3.6.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

sn35.120:3.7.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

sn35.120:3.8.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
sn35.120:3.8.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

sn35.120:3.9.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṃ, manindriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
sn35.120:3.9.eng: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.

sn35.120:3.10.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
sn35.120:3.10.eng: That’s how someone guards the sense doors.

sn35.120:4.1.eng: And how does someone eat in moderation?

sn35.120:4.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso āhāraṃ āhāreti:
sn35.120:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant reflects rationally on the food that they eat:

sn35.120:4.3.pli: ‘neva davāya, na madāya, na maṇḍanāya, na vibhūsanāya, yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā yāpanāya, vihiṃsūparatiyā, brahmacariyānuggahāya. Iti purāṇañca vedanaṃ paṭihaṅkhāmi, navañca vedanaṃ na uppādessāmi, yātrā ca me bhavissati, anavajjatā ca phāsuvihāro cā’ti.
sn35.120:4.3.eng: ‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will have the means to keep going, blamelessness, and a comfortable abiding.’

sn35.120:4.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhojane mattaññū hoti.
sn35.120:4.4.eng: That’s how someone eats in moderation.

sn35.120:5.1.eng: And how is someone committed to wakefulness?

sn35.120:5.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu divasaṃ caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṃ parisodheti.
sn35.120:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant practices walking and sitting meditation by day, purifying their mind from obstacles.

sn35.120:5.3.pli: Rattiyā paṭhamaṃ yāmaṃ caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṃ parisodheti.
sn35.120:5.3.eng: In the first watch of the night, they continue to practice walking and sitting meditation.

sn35.120:5.4.pli: Rattiyā majjhimaṃ yāmaṃ dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ kappeti pāde pādaṃ accādhāya sato sampajāno, uṭṭhānasaññaṃ manasi karitvā.
sn35.120:5.4.eng: In the middle watch, they lie down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.

sn35.120:5.5.pli: Rattiyā pacchimaṃ yāmaṃ paccuṭṭhāya caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṃ parisodheti.
sn35.120:5.5.eng: In the last watch, they get up and continue to practice walking and sitting meditation, purifying their mind from obstacles.

sn35.120:5.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, jāgariyaṃ anuyutto hoti.
sn35.120:5.6.eng: That’s how someone is committed to wakefulness.

sn35.120:5.7.eng: So you should train like this:

sn35.120:5.8.pli: ‘indriyesu guttadvārā bhavissāma, bhojane mattaññuno, jāgariyaṃ anuyuttā’ti.
sn35.120:5.8.eng: ‘We will guard the sense doors, eat in moderation, and be committed to wakefulness.’

sn35.121:0.2.eng: 12. The World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation

sn35.121:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn35.121:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn35.121:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavato rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn35.121:1.2.eng: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

sn35.121:1.3.eng: “The qualities that ripen in freedom have ripened in Rāhula.
sn35.121:1.3.comm: Five perceptions that ripen in freedom are taught at DN 33:2.1.139, but apart from that we do not encounter this idea in the discourses. | In SN 18.1–5, Rāhula requests a teaching so he can go on retreat. The teachings given there can be compared with the parallel, which says the Buddha first told Rāhula to teach the five aggregates, the six sense-spheres, and conditionality, and then to go on retreat and meditate on the same teachings (SA 200 at T ii 51a23). Only then did the Buddha consider him ready.

sn35.121:1.4.pli: yannūnāhaṃ rāhulaṃ uttariṃ āsavānaṃ khaye vineyyan”ti.
sn35.121:1.4.eng: Why don’t I lead him further to the ending of defilements?”

sn35.121:1.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā
sn35.121:1.5.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, wandered for alms in Sāvatthī.

sn35.121:1.6.eng: After the meal, on his return from almsround, he addressed Venerable Rāhula,

sn35.121:1.7.comm: The sitting cloth was a standard requisite of monastics (Bu Pc 89). Regularly featured in the texts of the Sarvāstivāda schools, it is rarely mentioned in the Pali suttas (but see DN 16:3.1.3).

sn35.121:1.8.eng: Let’s go to the Dark Forest for the day’s meditation.”

sn35.121:1.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā rāhulo bhagavato paṭissutvā nisīdanaṃ ādāya bhagavantaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhi.
sn35.121:1.9.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Rāhula. Taking his sitting cloth he followed behind the Buddha.

sn35.121:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena anekāni devatāsahassāni bhagavantaṃ anubandhāni honti:
sn35.121:2.1.eng: Now at that time many thousands of deities followed the Buddha, thinking,
sn35.121:2.1.comm: The presence of thousands of deities, which is unique to this discourse, is not mentioned in the Chinese parallel, and is obviously a later addition.

sn35.121:2.2.pli: “ajja bhagavā āyasmantaṃ rāhulaṃ uttariṃ āsavānaṃ khaye vinessatī”ti.
sn35.121:2.2.eng: “Today the Buddha will lead Rāhula further to the ending of defilements!”

sn35.121:2.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā andhavanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle paññatte āsane nisīdi.
sn35.121:2.3.eng: Then the Buddha plunged deep into the Dark Forest and sat at the root of a tree on the seat spread out.

sn35.121:2.4.pli: Āyasmāpi kho rāhulo bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
sn35.121:2.4.eng: Rāhula bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.

sn35.121:2.5.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ rāhulaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

sn35.121:3.2.eng: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.121:5.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.121:5.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.121:7.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn35.121:7.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.121:7.2.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.121:15.1.pli: “Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedanāgataṃ, saññāgataṃ, saṅkhāragataṃ, viññāṇagataṃ, tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.121:15.1.eng: “Anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises dependent on eye contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.121:17.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.121:17.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.121:19.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn35.121:19.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.121:19.2.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.121:27.1.pli: “Yampidaṃ jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedanāgataṃ, saññāgataṃ, saṅkhāragataṃ, viññāṇagataṃ, tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?

sn35.121:29.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?

sn35.121:31.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:

sn35.121:35.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.121:35.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.121:37.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ
sn35.121:37.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.121:37.2.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.121:45.1.pli: “Yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedanāgataṃ, saññāgataṃ, saṅkhāragataṃ, viññāṇagataṃ, tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.121:45.1.eng: “Anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises dependent on mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.121:47.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.121:47.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.121:49.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn35.121:49.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.121:49.2.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.121:51.1.pli: “Evaṃ passaṃ, rāhula, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati, rūpesupi nibbindati, cakkhuviññāṇepi nibbindati, cakkhusamphassepi nibbindati, yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedanāgataṃ saññāgataṃ saṅkhāragataṃ viññāṇagataṃ tasmimpi nibbindati …pe…
sn35.121:51.1.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they become disillusioned with anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises dependent on eye contact.

sn35.121:51.2.pli: jivhāyapi nibbindati, rasesupi nibbindati, jivhāviññāṇepi nibbindati, jivhāsamphassepi nibbindati, yampidaṃ jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedanāgataṃ saññāgataṃ saṅkhāragataṃ viññāṇagataṃ tasmimpi nibbindati …pe….
sn35.121:51.2.eng: They grow disillusioned with the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.121:52.1.pli: Manasmimpi nibbindati, dhammesupi nibbindati, manoviññāṇepi nibbindati, manosamphassepi nibbindati, yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedanāgataṃ saññāgataṃ saṅkhāragataṃ viññāṇagataṃ tasmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.121:52.1.eng: They grow disillusioned with the mind, ideas, mind consciousness, and mind contact. And they grow disillusioned with anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises dependent on mind contact.

sn35.121:52.2.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn35.121:52.2.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.121:52.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn35.121:52.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.121:53.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn35.121:53.2.pli: Attamano āyasmā rāhulo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandi.
sn35.121:53.2.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Rāhula approved what the Buddha said.

sn35.121:53.3.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne āyasmato rāhulassa anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimucci.
sn35.121:53.3.eng: And while this discourse was being spoken, Rāhula’s mind was freed from defilements by not grasping.

sn35.121:53.4.pli: Anekānañca devatāsahassānaṃ virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi:
sn35.121:53.4.eng: And the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in those thousands of deities:

sn35.121:53.5.eng: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”

sn35.122:0.2.eng: 12. The World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation

sn35.122:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the things that tighten the fetters, and the fetter.

sn35.122:1.3.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, saṃyojaniyā dhammā, katamañca saṃyojanaṃ?
sn35.122:1.3.eng: What are the things that tighten the fetters? And what is the fetter?

sn35.122:1.4.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.122:1.4.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.122:1.5.eng: These are called the things that tighten the fetters.

sn35.122:1.6.pli: Yo tattha chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ …pe…
sn35.122:1.6.eng: The desire and greed for them is the fetter.

sn35.122:1.7.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.122:1.8.pli: santi, bhikkhave, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.122:1.8.eng: thoughts known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.122:1.9.eng: These are called the things that tighten the fetters.

sn35.122:1.10.pli: Yo tattha chandarāgo taṃ tattha saṃyojanan”ti.
sn35.122:1.10.eng: The desire and greed for them is the fetter.”

sn35.123:0.2.eng: 12. The World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation

sn35.123:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the things that fuel grasping, and the grasping.

sn35.123:1.3.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, upādāniyā dhammā, katamañca upādānaṃ?
sn35.123:1.3.eng: What are the things that fuel grasping? And what is the grasping?

sn35.123:1.4.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.123:1.4.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.123:1.5.eng: These are called the things that fuel grasping.

sn35.123:1.6.pli: Yo tattha chandarāgo, taṃ tattha upādānaṃ …pe…
sn35.123:1.6.eng: The desire and greed for them is the grasping.

sn35.123:1.7.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.123:1.8.pli: santi, bhikkhave, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.123:1.8.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.123:1.9.eng: These are called the things that fuel grasping.

sn35.123:1.10.pli: Yo tattha chandarāgo taṃ tattha upādānan”ti.
sn35.123:1.10.eng: The desire and greed for them is the grasping.”

sn35.124:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
sn35.124:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

sn35.124:1.2.pli: Atha kho uggo gahapati vesāliko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho uggo gahapati vesāliko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.124:1.2.eng: Then the householder Ugga of Vesālī went up to the Buddha, sat down to one side, and said to him:
sn35.124:1.2.comm: Ugga was the foremost in giving nice things (AN 1.253), a quality exemplified at AN 5.44. This Ugga (“of Vesalī”) and the Uggata of the next discourse (“of Elephant Village” near Vesalī) are both said to have eight excellent qualities (AN 8.21, AN 8.22).

sn35.124:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme no parinibbāyanti?
sn35.124:1.3.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are not fully extinguished in this very life?

sn35.124:1.4.pli: Ko pana, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme parinibbāyantī”ti?
sn35.124:1.4.eng: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in this very life?”

sn35.124:2.1.pli: “Santi kho, gahapati, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.124:2.1.eng: “Householder, there are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.124:2.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati. Tassa taṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato tannissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ hoti tadupādānaṃ.
sn35.124:2.2.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them, their consciousness has that as support and fuel for grasping.

sn35.124:2.3.eng: A mendicant with fuel for grasping does not become extinguished.

sn35.124:2.4.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.124:2.5.pli: santi kho, gahapati, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.124:2.5.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.124:2.6.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati. Tassa taṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato tannissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ hoti tadupādānaṃ.
sn35.124:2.6.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them, their consciousness has that as support and fuel for grasping.

sn35.124:2.7.eng: A mendicant with fuel for grasping does not become extinguished.

sn35.124:2.8.pli: Ayaṃ kho, gahapati, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme no parinibbāyanti.
sn35.124:2.8.eng: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are not fully extinguished in this very life.

sn35.124:3.1.pli: Santi ca kho, gahapati, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.124:3.1.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.124:3.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati. Tassa taṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato na tannissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ hoti, na tadupādānaṃ.
sn35.124:3.2.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, their consciousness doesn’t have that as support and fuel for grasping.

sn35.124:3.3.eng: A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.

sn35.124:3.4.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.124:3.5.pli: santi kho, gahapati, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.124:3.5.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.124:3.6.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati, tassa taṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato. Na tannissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ hoti, na tadupādānaṃ.
sn35.124:3.6.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, their consciousness doesn’t have that as support and fuel for grasping.

sn35.124:3.7.eng: A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.

sn35.124:3.8.pli: Ayaṃ kho, gahapati, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme parinibbāyantī”ti.
sn35.124:3.8.eng: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in this very life.”

sn35.125:0.3.eng: In the Land of the Vajjis

sn35.125:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vajjīsu viharati hatthigāme.
sn35.125:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Vajjis at Elephant Village.

sn35.125:1.2.pli: Atha kho uggo gahapati hatthigāmako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho uggo gahapati hatthigāmako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.125:1.2.eng: Then the householder Uggata of Elephant Village went up to the Buddha, sat down to one side, and said to him:
sn35.125:1.2.comm: At AN 1.254 and AN 6.126 he is called Uggata, which I adopt for clarity over text’s Ugga here.

sn35.125:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme no parinibbāyanti?
sn35.125:1.3.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are not fully extinguished in this very life?

sn35.125:1.4.pli: Ko pana, bhante, hetu ko paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme parinibbāyantī”ti?
sn35.125:1.4.eng: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in this very life?” …

sn35.125:1.5.eng: (Tell in full as in the previous discourse.)

sn35.125:1.6.pli: “Ayaṃ kho, gahapati, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme parinibbāyantī”ti.

sn35.126:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā nāḷandāyaṃ viharati pāvārikambavane.
sn35.126:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Nāḷandā in Pāvārika’s mango grove.

sn35.126:1.2.pli: Atha kho, upāli gahapati, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho, upāli gahapati, bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.126:1.2.eng: Then the householder Upāli went up to the Buddha … and asked him,
sn35.126:1.2.comm: Upāli’s conversion is related at MN 56.

sn35.126:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme no parinibbāyanti?
sn35.126:1.3.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are not fully extinguished in this very life?

sn35.126:1.4.pli: Ko pana, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme parinibbāyantī”ti?
sn35.126:1.4.eng: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in this very life?” …

sn35.126:1.6.pli: “Ayaṃ kho, gahapati, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme parinibbāyantī”ti.
